descriptionProfile: Randy Olson is founder of @thephotosociety and has produced more than 30 stories for National Geographic magazine.
and has produced more than 30 stories for National Geographic magazine.

posts.description: This signed print is available thru my agency for $100 until 4/22. The aquifer-fed Platte River is a roosting area for roughly 413,000 sandhill cranes as they migrate between northern Mexico and Siberia. This shot was taken as an evening storm rolled into the Nebraska plains just as the birds were beginning to land for the night. It was published in the August 2016 issue of National Geographic magazine. Purchase signed prints of this image for $100 from April 17th - April 22nd in honor of Earth Day. Click on the link in my profile to see all the signed prints featured in @natgeocreative’s Flash Sale! #earthday #conservation #platteriver #nebraska #lightning #sandhillcrane

This camel beauty contest in #SaudiArabia is an entire city in the middle of the desert… but I am inside judging… so this photo is from the last camel beauty contest I photographed in the empty quarter. @thephotosociety @natgeocreative
Speaking tonight in #Toronto about #water issues. No one knows water issues better than @ddimick shown here strolling on an #Oregon beach. @natgeo @natgeocreative @thephotosociety

Muleshoe TX - A farmer has painted these 50 gallon drums to look like cows and he’s pulling kids around the deserted Central Business District (CBD) of Muleshoe TX on Halloween. The kids are there for a “trunk or treat” where they drive to the CBD and open their trunks full of candy for the kids. In rural areas it’s just too far to go from farm to farm for one piece of candy. @natgeo @natgeocreative @thephotosociety

There are six great aquifers in the world. In North America our great aquifer is the Ogallala—it stretches from South Dakota to the Texas panhandle. Twenty percent of our food and 40 percent of our beef rely on the aquifer. It’s unfortunate that we’ve pumped the equivalent of two Lake Eries out, setting the stage for a new desert in the Texas panhandle and southern Kansas in the immediate future.

The aquifer recharges at different rates. Nebraska wins the water lottery; it is the only place you can see Ogallala water at the surface. The Ogallala takes a long time to recharge in Texas, where there are the most wells, the least regulation, the hottest temperatures (even before climate change), and the slowest recharge. Entire communities in this area are already running out of water.

Scarcity of water, fragile infrastructure, small dust bowls, the family farm crisis, Big Ag, and global urbanization leave some behind with few options. Small towns are disintegrating around their residents. There is rampant meth and opioid addiction in some of these places. If your hot water heater breaks, there isn’t anyone in your entire county that can fix it.

I am from the Midwest, and the pain rural folks have gone through showed up this election. I saw this frustration first-hand working on the Ogallala aquifer story that ran in the August 2016 issue of National Geographic, but I never thought the level of frustration of these communities would manifest itself in this way. @natgeo @natgeocreative @thephotosociety

Wood River Nebraska - This was the last night of the last trip for an @natgeo assignment on the Ogallala Aquifer. I had bedded down in the blind when the cranes started to land for the night just outside… then the storm rolled in. Sand Hill Cranes are the grassland birds of the great plains. They migrate from Siberia to northern Mexico. They counted 413,000 Sandhill Cranes on this evening… more than they’ve ever counted before. These conservation groups are working like crazy to keep 20 miles of the Platte River braided and perfect habitat for the cranes that come through their area. @thephotosociety @natgeo @natgeocreative
Photo by @randyolson Portales New Mexico… this night just feels like Twin Peaks to me… @natgeo @natgeocreative @thephotosociety

Muleshoe TX - Central Business District (CBD) - Many of the businesses are for sale in the CBD or just boarded up. As the water runs out in the Ogallala aquifer, smaller towns in this area will dry up and disappear first. @natgeo @natgeocreative @thephotosociety
Garden City KS - Beef Empire Days Ranch Riding competition - Portrait of Rancher James Bond. @natgeo @natgeocreative @thephotosociety

Just across the state line from the Berdoza family are 88,000 agricultural wells tapping the Ogallala aquifer in the TX panhandle. The Berdoza family has been carrying water in 5 gallon buckets in the back of a pickup for FOUR YEARS. … they need to haul 105 gallons a day to meet their water needs and give their children bucket baths. @natgeo @natgeocreative @thephotosociety

Mennonite child on school bus piloted by Superintendent Joanna Martinez who wears many hats and is trying to figure out how to keep the school and community alive as they run out of water. She had 90 days of water left for 16 families. There are 88,000 wells around her in the TX panhandle and the area has the least water from the aquifer underneath, the least regulation, and the least recharge. @natgeo @natgeocreative @thephotosociety

Muleshoe TX - Central Business District (CBD) - Many of the businesses are for sale in the CBD or just boarded up. In general as the water runs out in the Ogallala aquifer, smaller towns in this area will dry up and disappear first. To be FAIR… There is a strip of McDonald’s like businesses outside the CBD… and the town does claim the smallest TV station run by a wonderful mother and son team. To see the video they did of me google Muleshoe Channel 6 and Randy Olson. @natgeo @natgeocreative @thephotosociety

Lazbuddie Texas the school superintendent also drives the school bus, and she is trying to figure out how to keep the school and community alive as they run out of water. At one point, she only had 90 days of water left for 16 families (teachers are housed at school complex). The well got down to 15 feet of standing water. Lazbuddie as well as towns all the way north to South Dakota depend on the Ogallala aquifer. There are 88,000 wells around her in the TX panhandle and the area has the least water from the aquifer underneath, the least regulation, the least recharge and the highest density of wells. On assignment @natgeo story. @natgeocreative @thephotosociety #schools #education #transportation #schoolbus

Photo by @randyolson Garden City, Kansas - Beef Empire Days - The beef culture creates the high plains culture of cowboys and rodeo queens - a place where a girl can dream of being a cow girl out on the range. @natgeocreative @thephotosociety
